title: Arctic Tern: The Ultimate Migration
description: Follow the Arctic Tern on the longest migration journey of any animal on Earth - a 44,000-mile round trip from pole to pole.

funFacts: Arctic Terns experience two summers per year, seeing more daylight than any other creature on Earth
They can live up to 30 years, traveling over 1.5 million miles in their lifetime
Their migration route follows a zigzag pattern to take advantage of prevailing winds
Some individuals fly up to 56,000 miles per year - equivalent to three trips to the Moon over their lifetime

hotspots.title: Breeding Grounds - Iceland
hotspots.content: Arctic Terns breed in the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions during the Northern Hemisphere summer. Iceland's coastal areas provide ideal nesting sites with abundant fish and long daylight hours.

media.caption: Arctic Tern colonies can contain thousands of nesting pairs

hotspots.title: North Atlantic Departure
hotspots.content: After breeding, Arctic Terns begin their epic journey south. They follow the coastlines and oceanic currents, feeding on small fish and krill along the way. The North Atlantic leg takes advantage of favorable winds.

media.caption: Terns can travel 500+ miles per day during migration

hotspots.title: West African Coast
hotspots.content: The nutrient-rich waters off West Africa provide crucial feeding opportunities. Arctic Terns often follow the productive upwelling zones where cold, nutrient-dense water rises to the surface, supporting abundant marine life.

media.caption: Upwelling zones are vital refueling stations for migrating seabirds

hotspots.title: Southern Ocean Crossing
hotspots.content: The vast Southern Ocean presents both challenges and opportunities. Arctic Terns navigate by the sun and stars, and likely use Earth's magnetic field. They often follow a zigzag pattern to exploit the strongest tailwinds.

media.caption: The Southern Ocean's westerly winds provide crucial flight assistance

hotspots.title: Antarctic Waters - Wintering Grounds
hotspots.content: Arctic Terns reach Antarctic waters to experience the Southern Hemisphere summer. Pack ice edges provide rich feeding grounds where they hunt for Antarctic krill and small fish, building up energy reserves for the return journey.

media.caption: Arctic Terns experience 24-hour daylight in both polar summers

hotspots.title: Journey Complete
hotspots.content: After 9-12 months, Arctic Terns return to their breeding grounds, often to the exact same nesting site. This incredible journey of up to 56,000 miles demonstrates one of nature's most remarkable feats of endurance and navigation.

media.caption: Site fidelity ensures terns return to successful breeding locations year after year
